Jennifer Pouplin PhD Candidate under the supervision of Dr. David A Minton

About Me Projects

My Expertise

I am a PhD candidate in Astrodynamics and Space Applications at Purdue University. As part of my dissertation work, I am applying my skills in Planetary Sciences, by modeling the orbital evolution of planetary rings and satellites systems, such as the hypothesized ancient martian ring system, or the contemporary ring system around Chariklo.

Engineering

I have an extensive engineering background. I graduated from Ecole des Mines de Nancy, France with a Bachelor and Master of Sc., followed by a double diploma at Purdue University in Aeronautics and Astronautics.

Coding

I have developed extensive programming skills through my PhD work, mainly in Python and Fortran, but I have also used Matlab, Maple, Visual Basic, and C.

Science

I developed my planetary science knowledge through projects and coursework at Purdue University, participating in many concept mission design studies and an analogue astronaut mission.

Scholarships, Honors, and Awards

I have been fortunate to have my work recognized through the years by many scholarships and awards. The support I have received has allowed me to explore the field of planetary science and continue my PhD journey.

Current Projects

Martian Moons

I am developing an N-body dynamics accretion model called Swiftest, that uses fragmentation, tidal evolution, and ring/moons evolution to reconcile observable properties of Phobos and Deimos with their formation via giant-Martian impact debris disk hypothesis.

The Importance of Being Swiftest: The effects of collisional fragmentation on the accretion timescale of the martian moons and the terrestrial planets. (Talk) Pouplin, J., Wishard, C., Elliott, J., Minton, D. (2020)
Swiftest: An N-body dynamics code incorporating collisional regime determination and fragmentation (Poster) Wishard, C., Pouplin, J., Elliott, J., Minton, D. (2020)
Evidence for a Past Martian Ring from the Orbital Inclination of Deimos (Paper) Cuk, M., Minton, D., Pouplin, J., Wishard., C. (2020)
The origin of Miranda from a massive early ring at Uranus. (Talk) Minton D., Hesselbrock, A., Pouplin, J. (2019)

Chariklo and Transneptunian objects

Using Swiftest, we are trying to estimate ring stability and timescales around Trans-Neptunian Objects and small bodies such as Chariklo, using numerical and experimental data.

Past Projects

Caltech Space Challenge 2019

I participated on the science design of a mission to Enceladus, indented to understand how Enceladus provides habitable conditions, and characterize its biotic and abiotic signatures.

Assessing the Habitability of an Active Ocean World: the Etna Mission Concept to Enceladus' Tiger Stripes. Venigalla, C., Deutsch, A., Panicucci, P., Peytavi, G.G., Pouplin, J., Tenelanda-Osorio, L., Guarriello, A., Specia, E.C., Cho, Y.H., Da-Poian, V., Gunasekara, O., Jones, L., Krasteva, M., Mathanlal, T., Villanueva, N., Zaref., S. (2020)

Genetic Algorithm

I developed a genetic algorithm tool to predict impactor properties for lunar craters based on their geometry.

A Genetic Optimization Tool for Predicting Lunar Impactor Properties Based on Observed Crater Diameter. (Poster). Elliott, J., Pouplin, J. (2018)

Fortune: Concept Mission Design Study

I designed the telecommunication, command & data handling and the scientific subsystems for a CubeSat mission to a Near-Earth Asteroid for the student competition for the 2017 Astrodynamics Specialist Conference.

Fortune: A Multi-CubeSat, Near-Earth Asteroid Prospecting Mission. (Poster) Elliott, J., Shibata, E., Wistberger, P.A., Pouplin, J.m, Rolley, R., Podesta, L.P, Ianev, J.D. (2017)

Human Journey to Mars

I lead a team of 30 students for a one-year research project on complex concept mission for Human colonization and exploration of the Martian soil. (Fall 2016)

Check it out

OCEANUS: Concept Mission Design Study

I developed analytical tools for the complete concept study of a flagship mission to Uranus with a Saturn Flyby. I designed the command and data handling system and the telecommunications system. I also defined the scientific objectives and the instrument payload for the mission.

Oceanus: A multi-spacecraft flagship mission concept to explore Saturn and Uranus. Mansell, J., Kolencherry, N., HUghes, K., Arora, A., Chye, H.S, Coleman, K., Elliott, J., Fulton, S., Hobar, N., Libben, B., Lu, Y., Millane, J., Mudek, A., Podesta, L., Pouplin, J., Shibata, E., Smith, G., Tackett, B., Ukai, T., Witsberger, P., Saikia, S. (2017)

Mobility System for Icy Moon Exploration

I participated in the design of a innovative rover concept for Icy Moons Exploration able to survive extreme conditions.

Icy Moon Mobility System Analysis Tool. (Talk) Podesta, L.P., Vutukuri, S., Pouplin, J., Ho, S.C., Droll, I., Saikia, S.J. (2016) Mobility Technology For Enceladus Terrain Accessibility (MT. ETNA). (Poster) Witsberger, P.A., Podesta, L.P., Shibata, E., Potter, R., Anderson, A.J., Coleman, K.W.C., Futton, S.J., Guven, C., Ho, S.C., Hobar, N., Hock, E.E., Klug, L., Lucas, R., Machuca, P., Matlock, S., Mudek, A., Pouplin, J., Reinart, A.M., Rolley, R.,J., Sharpless, D., Saikia, S.J. (2016)

Determination of the composition of wildfire gases

I developed a Matlab model using swarm particles optimization to determine more accurately the content of dioxygen, dihydrogen, carbon dioxide, carbon monoxide, and soot in wildfires gases.

Study of a V-shape flame based on IR spectroscopy and IR imaging. (Paper) Pouplin, J., Collin, A., Acem, Z., Parent, G., Boulet, P., Vena, P., Galizzi, C., Kühni, M., André, F., and Escudié, D. (2015)
